item.title: Octopilot
item.description:
In 2020, while building Dailymotion’s new Continuous Delivery platform, I found myself needing a tool to automate the creation of pull requests to implement our Gitops-based workflow. No existing tool really matches our needs, so I created Octopilot: a CLI tool designed to help you automate your Gitops workflow, by automatically creating and merging GitHub Pull Requests to update specific content in Git repositories.

You can read more about Octopilot in a blog post I wrote on Medium: Introducing Octopilot: a CLI to automate the creation of GitHub pull requests in your gitops workflow.

item.title: Jenkins X Projects
item.description:

item.title: Story of Our Transition to a Custom Kubernetes Operator for an API Gateway
item.description:
At the KubeCon Europe 2023 Conference, I gave a talk titled Story of Our Transition to a Custom Kubernetes Operator for an API Gateway.

In this talk, I shared our challenges at Ubisoft, and why we decided to write our own Kubernetes Operator, instead of relying on existing solutions.

I explained our platform’s conventions, and how we are using OpenAPI as a central point of entry for our APIs. And I detailled the features we needed - and implemented - to automatically configure our API Gateway based on the OpenAPI documents provided by the different services.

item.title: Comment OpenTelemetry peut transformer votre monitoring en unifiant vos logs/metrics/traces

In this talk, I our experience using OpenTelemetry at Ubisoft, and how it helped us to unify our monitoring data.

I shared how we use the OpenTelemetry Collector in a Kubernetes environment, and a unified platform based on Grafana Tempo, Loki and Prometheus.

You can read the slides on SpeakerDeck.

item.title: How Jenkins X is Integrating Observability from the Inside, and the Benefits for its Users
item.description:

In this talk, I explained what observability means for a Continuous Delivery platform such as Jenkins X, and why it’s important.

I went through how Jenkins X v3 is integrating observability from the inside, using standards such as OpenTelemetry, and packaging a full observability stack using Grafana - with Loki, Promtail, Tempo, and Prometheus.

item.description:

item.title: Jenkins X Pipelines Internals
item.description:
While migrating pipelines from the Jenkins Declarative Syntax to the new Jenkins X YAML Syntax - built on top of Tekton - I learned a lot about the internals of the Jenkins X Pipelines, and wrote a series of blog posts to share what I learned:

  • The first part is a walk-through of a GitHub WebHook event coming to the cluster until it results in a running Tekton Pipeline. It explains how Prow understands the webhook event, “kind of” forwards it to Jenkins X, which retrieves the right pipeline to execute and translate it into a format that Tekton can understand.
  • The second part dives into the “Meta Pipeline”: the part of the workflow which is responsible for retrieving the right pipeline to execute, and to translate it into a format that Tekton can understand.
  • The third and fourth parts are focused on the stages and steps that compose a pipeline.

You can read the series on Medium.

item.description:

item.description:

  • how we promote our releases to staging/production on different Kubernetes clusters using Helmfile – and the benefits of it.

item.description:

item.description:

In this talk, we explained how we are using Go to build our new ad-tech platform REST APIs:

item.title: Various OpenShift-related projects
item.description:
In 2015-2016, while using OpenShift, I developed a few small open-source projects on top of the Kubernetes/OpenShift APIs:

  • OpenShift Dashboard
  • OpenShift Cucumber
  • OpenShift GitHub Hooks
  • OpenShift/Git Integration
  • OpenShift Flowdock Notifier

OpenShift Dashboard

When I started using OpenShift, I quickly realized that it was missing a global view of the cluster state. In August 2015 I developed a Web Dashboard for visualization of multi-projects resources in OpenShift.

This gave me the opportunity to learn the OpenShift/Kubernetes API early on, and improve my Go skills - by reading the OpenShift and Kubernetes code bases.

item.title: Continuous Deployment with Jenkins and Rundeck
item.description:
At the Paris DevOps meetup, at the march 2011 session, I gave a talk titled Continuous Deployment with Jenkins and Rundeck with my colleague Bruno.

Bruno presented Rundeck first, and how it can be used to automate operations.

And then I explained how we used it at RTL, to build a Continuous Deployment pipeline using Jenkins and Nexus:

  • for our staging environment, we enabled a continuous deployment workflow - which we called “0-click deployment”
  • for our production environment, we enabled a continuous delivery workflow - which we called “1-click deployment”

Read the full meetup report - in french.

item.title: Jenkins X
item.description:
Jenkins X is a CI/CD platform on top of Kubernetes. I started using it while it was still a young project, in september 2018.

I made various contributions:

  • code, of course - including bug fixes and new features
  • documentation and blog posts on the Jenkins X blog
  • support on the community Slack channels
  • demos at Office Hours - see recordings on YouTube
  • talks at conferences and meetups, and interviews on podcasts
  • …

I also got a few awards, such as:

item.title: Jenkins Rundeck Plugin
item.description:
In 2011, I wrote a Jenkins plugin to integrate Rundeck as a “publisher”: the Rundeck plugin.

This plugin allows the creation of continuous delivery pipelines, using Jenkins to build your software and Rundeck to deploy it. I talked about it at the Paris DevOps meetup in march 2011: Continuous Deployment with Jenkins and Rundeck.

Note that this plugin is now maintained by the Rundeck team, and is still used by many people.

item.title: Helm Ecosystem
item.description:
Helm is a package manager for Kubernetes. It is the tool most people use to package their applications, and then deploy on Kubernetes. It is also the core of an ecosystem growing every day: plugins, wrapper tools, charts, …

I have been contributing to a few open-source projects in the Helm ecosystem:

  • Helmfile - a “declarative spec for deploying helm charts”
  • Helm Unit Tests plugin - a plugin for running unit tests on Helm charts
  • Helm Tiller plugin - a plugin for running Helm in “tiller-less” mode in Helm 2
  • Helm charts - various contributions to common charts I’ve been using

item.title: Rundeck API Java Client
item.description:
In 2011, following the Jenkins Rundeck plugin, I extracted the code that talked to the Rundeck REST API into its own project: the Rundeck API Java Client.

The goal was to be able to write more software in Java using Rundeck’s REST API, for example the Rundeck Remote CLI, or writing scripts

Note that this project is now maintained by the Rundeck team at rundeck/rundeck-api-java-client, and is still used by many projects/people.

item.title: Osiris
item.description:
Osiris is “a general purpose, scale-to-zero component for Kubernetes”. As explained in the Zero cost preview environments on Kubernetes with Jenkins X and Osiris blog post I wrote, Osiris is an excellent tool to keep a Jenkins X cluster size under control.

I contributed multiple new features and bug fixes to Osiris.

As the original project has now been archived, I’m maintaining a fork on the Dailymotion OSS organization - as well as how to use it in Jenkins X.

item.title: Kaniko
item.description:
Kaniko is “a tool to build container images from a Dockerfile, inside a container or Kubernetes cluster”.

In 2018 when I started using Jenkins X to power our CI/CD pipelines on Kubernetes, I quickly identified Kaniko to build our container images.

Unfortunately, as explained in the Dailymotion’s journey from Jenkins to Jenkins X blog post I wrote, I found a few bugs which I fixed in Kaniko:

  • Fix for multi-stage builds
  • Fix to allow building multiple images using the same container

I also added a few new features:

item.title: Flowdock to Elasticsearch
item.description:
In 2014, I wanted to play with Elasticsearch and Kibana, so I created a small project to import data from a Flowdock instance into Elasticsearch, and then build a Kibana dashboard to visualize the Flowdock usage.

It is written in Scala and uses the Flowdock REST API to retrieve data, and the Elastic4s scala lib to populate the Elasticsearch index. I also contributed to the Elastic4s open-source project.

Here is a screenshot of the Kibana dashboard:

item.title: OpenShift
item.description:
OpenShift is a Kubernetes “distribution” developed by Red Hat.

In the summer of 2015 I started using this newly announced platform, and as always when working with new projects, found a lot of opportunities for improvements.

This is how I contributed new features, bug fixes, bug reports and documentation in:

  • OpenShift Origin - including support for custom Dockerfile path when building Docker images
  • OpenShift source-to-image - the tool used to build container images without using Dockerfiles
  • OpenShift Documentation

I also contributed to the OpenShift completion for oh-my-zsh plugin.

item.title: Cascading Flapi
item.description:
In 2013, we were using Hadoop at Exalead, writing data processing pipelines with Cascading. But Cascading’s Java API was… not very friendly to use.

I wanted a more “fluent” API, so I wrote an OSS project on top of Cascading to provide a fluent API. I used Flapi, which is an API generator for Java, “generating ‘smart’ interfaces for improved fluency in your code”.

The cascading-flapi project was used at Exalead to help write our data processing pipelines… until switching to Spark.

item.title: Elastic4s
item.description:
Elastic4s is an Elasticsearch client for Scala.

In 2014, while working on a Scala-based CMS - Content Management System - with an integrated search engine based on Elasticsearch, I found myself using the Elastic4s open-source project. And as it often happens, not all our use-cases were covered by the existing features, so I contributed a few new features.

See all my contributions.

At some point I also became a committer on the project.

While I don’t use this project anymore, it is still alive and used by companies such as Barclays Bank, HSBC, Shazaam, Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, Canal +, Soundcloud, …

item.title: Paris DevOps
item.description:

item.title: Rundeck
item.description:
Rundeck is an “open source automation service”. As explained in the Continuous Deployment with Jenkins and Rundeck talk I gave in 2011, Rundeck is an excellent tool to build a Continuous Deployment pipeline, on top of Jenkins.

I wrote a few contributions to Rundeck.
